bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, December 7, 1901

div1.p: Louise Kean writes about the Keans' travels, her daughter's ear infections, and a case of experimental yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, December 7, 1901
div1.p:
Your nice, long
letter to Helen came to-
day, but, as the Bunnie
Sister, is very much used
up today I will answer
some of your questions.
You must send all
packages to Rannie, for
then they are passed
through the custom house.
Registered mail seems to
be about one week in
coming. I think you had
better send bundles to
this address, then Rannie
is not bothered to bring
them out from town-
Columbia B'ks, Cuba, is
all the address needed,
for this is a P. O. of itself.
The veils came very prompt-
ly, and thanks for the
white ribbon, it is a
great boon. Be sure and
let me know if the
five pesos I sent last
month were enough for
the slippers and veils.

Rannie left yesterday
for Puerto Principe, and
I am afraid he won't
be back before the 20th.
There is a norther blow-
ing now, so I imagine
Rannie is being very much
tossed around, as he goes
down the north coast to
Nuevitas, and Rannie is such a poor sailor.
Yesterday we had a nice little trip to
Morro & Cabaña. Capt. Foltz of the 2nd Cao.
(the chief or boss of the Havana police) had
made two efforts to take us, but each
time Martha's sickness prevented us, but
finally, yesterday I felt I could go, so
we three went into town on the eleven
o'clock train. Capt. Foltz's carriage met
us at Concha and we went to his
house to luncheon. Ourselves, Capt. F., Lieut.
Wells & Col. Noyes were the party. After lunch
we boarded a launch and went over
to Morro, then we walked to Cabaña and
went over that. As it was a heavenly
day the views were beautiful. Then Capt.
Foltz took us all around the harbor in
his launch, we even went a little way
outside of the Morro, to get the lovely colors
in the water and on the sides of the
old castle. Our carriage met us at the
wharf and we reached home about
half past five, rather tired, but having
had a most satisfactory day.

Tonight there is to be a hop. Mr. Wells
and Mr. Ginty (one of the new lieutenants here)
are coming to dinner.

The poor Bun seems to
be out of it tonight, I
am sorry to say.

Martha is very much
better, and allowed to
go out, tho' still some-
what deaf. Her leftright, ear
finally began to discharge,
and the Dr., found the
drum a little perforated,
but if she had an
abcess of the inner ear I
don't see why she didn't
suffer more- The discharge
has stopped now and when
I get out the wax hasthat seems
to have accumulated in her
left ear, and the cotton out
of her right, I think she
will be able to hear well
again. Dr. Howard has
given me a tonic for her,
for she looks very white
a thin since her five
days in bed. Mr. Bobs
is blooming, and getting
so cunning. We will have
some more pictures of
him to send you soon.

I am surprised Rannie
wrote you about Dick's
experimental case of yellow
fever, for Dick does not
want the news to reach
his mother, so made
us promise not to tell.
It came off in October,
while Dr. Carroll was
here, and he had a
very mild case, but per-
fectly clearly marked. Helen will have
to write you all the details and the
whys and wherefares, for I haven't time
today. I went over to see Dick while
he was sick in bed.

I am glad to hear Dollie is having
a good time in Boston- Give my love
to Tom and all the family
div1.closer:
As ever your very loving Louise The N. A. squadron is due here
on the 17th. Another reason for Miss
Bun to put off her return.
